DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Close Lower
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices fell moderately Friday after a survey of Chicago purchasing executives indicated strength in the manufacturing sector of the economy. The Treasury's 30-year bond fell 5-32 point, or about $1.56 per $1,000 face amount. Its yield edged up to 7.97 percent from 7.96 percent late Thursday. Analysts said an initial report that Chicago purchasing managers were reporting a slowdown in the economy gave the market a lift, but when the report was corrected, showing strength among industrial firms, bond prices turned downward. Traders believe the Federal Reserve is more likely to relax credit and allow interest rates to fall if the economy is slowing. The report of a pickup in the economy led them to believe the Fed would not push rates downward. The National Association of Purchasing Management will issue its monthly survey on the economy next week. Traders are looking to that report and the government's unemployment figures for possible signals on how the Fed might act. Trading was extremely light Friday as most traders had closed their books for the year. The federal funds rate, often an important reflection of the Fed's credit policy, fell dramatically as the central bank added funds to the system to help banks meet their yearend needs. The rate, which closed at 9} percent on Thursday, fell to 7{ percent. Analysts said the extra reserves were needed by banks for the long weekend. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments were unchanged to 1-32 point lower, intermediate maturities were off 1-16 point and long-term issues were down about 3-16 point, according to Telerate Inc., the financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 0.93 to 1,188.41. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.82 percent as the discount dropped 9 basis points to 7.58 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 7.99 percent as the discount picked up 7 basis points to close at 7.59 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 7.75 percent as the discount rose 1 basis point to 7.24 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose 1-16 point to 93 14-32. The average yield to maturity was unchanged at 7.25 percent.
